title: Positive Global and Local News Combine to Create Mini-Bull Run for Indian Markets
text:
is in the middle of a mini-bull run as the index has made smart gains in the last six of the seven sessions. Nifty and Sensex are both up 4% in the previous seven sessions.

Let’s start with some of the global factors influencing this run. Last week the markets cheered the thaw in the US-China trade war with the talks making good progress. The uncertainty created by the trade war had taken a toll on the global economy, with countries resorting to fiscal and monetary stimulus measures to revive growth. It included India, for which the GDP growth declined to a low of 5% in the June-ending quarter.

Yesterday, markets cheered the comments from the European Commission that the Brexit deal with the UK has been reached. Although the deal is yet to be approved by the UK parliament, nonetheless, it is a step in the right direction and will go a long way in reviving the global economy.

Talking about some of the local factors, investor’s sentiments were boosted by Indian Finance Minister’s comments that we can expect more reforms to be announced in the current fiscal year to boost the GDP growth. She also mentioned that to revive the stressed sectors, the government will take sector-specific measures. No wonder Nifty Auto and Nifty PSU Bank indices shot up by 3.13% and 3.0%, respectively, in yesterday’s trade. Auto and PSU Bank sectors are the most stressed sectors currently, and FM’s statement bodes well for these.

The FM has already announced several stimulus packages to revive the economy. was hailed as the most significant reform in the Indian economy in decades. The FM has also already announced other smaller stimulus packages for banks, infrastructure, automobile, and real estate sectors. Hence, it will be interesting to see what other packages the FM will announce in the coming days.

Then finally, the favorable prices are a significant support to the Indian economy as India meets 80% of its oil needs through Imports. Crude prices have stabilized at around $54 as geopolitical tensions have subsided for now, while the global economic slowdown has impacted the demand for oil.
